title: What counts as historical evidence? - Quora

response.answer_text: That depends on whether you’re willing to accept assertions or not. Some people accept the Bible as evidence. I accept only objective evidence. So the Bible is definitely evidence - that it was written. But it makes no biological sense that 7+ billion people evolved from a single pair even 9,000 years ago (and Göbekli Tepe, going back at least 9,000 years, tells us that there were people building things a lot before 6,000 years ago), and in so many different forms. Or that, on a planet with the amount of water Earth has (counting water vapor, liquid water, snow and ice), something caused it to expand to be more than 29,000 feet deeper than it is now. (It couldn’t have fallen “from above” - we’ve been “above” and there are no great reserves of water up there - and 29,000 feet of water falling in 40 days would have sterilized the planet [falling water releases heat].) The monotheistic Sumerians living in Ur didn’t travel to “Egypt”, become slaves, build the pyramids for 400 years, then “escape” to Canaan, vanquishing the local residents - we’ve found physical evidence on the ground that tells us that Canaan was part of Egypt in the 13th century BCE, that the people living there came from Ur, not living somewhere else for 400 years, that the pyramid builders were skilled craftsmen, not slaves, that the residents of Canaan for more than 400 years before Rameses the Great (and until about 600 years after he died) were polytheists (as were all people in those days) … so which one is “evidence”, the things we actually find sitting there? Or one single book (that’s been changed with almost every copying - read the Codex Sinaiticus, then compare it to any modern Bible) that makes claims that couldn’t be proved either way when it was written - but can be disproved now?
